Award.AwardTitle: Origin and Vertical Extent of Damage Zones Around Continental Strike-slip Faults
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objectives of this project are to: (1) scale-up a preliminary micromechanical model for grain-scale coseismic damage spanning the seismogenic zone that integrates analytical (electron backscatter diffraction and cathodoluminescence) and computational (asymptotic expansion homogenization) approaches and fully account for the grain-scale elastic interactions among the different minerals in the sample; (2) apply this integrated framework to quantify the effects of damage and other fault-zone microstructure on seismic anisotropy; (3) determine the spatial and temporal pattern of damage and related seismogenic structure around an ancient strike-slip fault (the Norumbega fault in Maine) exhumed from a depth of approximately 10-15 km; (4) develop a conceptual model linking this pattern to the damage structure of active faults observed at the surface; and (5) disseminate open-source software for damage analysis and calculation of bulk elastic stiffnesses and seismic properties of damaged rocks. This software will take input either from electron backscatter diffraction data files of natural microstructures, or synthetic (computer generated) microstructures that can be used in sensitivity analyses among other applications.

Strike-slip faults like the San Andreas Fault in California represent major threats to life and property owing to the repeated generation of large earthquakes. During each earthquake, the rocks surrounding the ruptured segment of the fault are fragmented by cracking of individual mineral grains. Over many earthquake cycles, these rocks become so damaged that they strongly affect the elastic properties of the rocks, and therefore the speed and preferred propagation direction of seismic waves. Although these so-called damage zones are of great importance for seismic hazards, a robust mechanical model for how they form is lacking, and there is almost no information on the vertical extent of this damage within active fault zones. Furthermore, there is currently no computational framework available for calculating how progressive damage evolution might affect seismic wave propagation. The combination of modeling and field-based results from this work will allow improved characterization of seismically active areas, including conceptual and wave speed models that can be used to better predict ground shaking directions and intensities. The open-source codes developed in this project will be made available through existing public portals, and will have many community applications including the relationships between microcrack orientation and state of stress, interpretation of seismological data, and analysis of brittle damage and fragmentation of ceramics and advanced composite materials. Recognition of the importance of microfracturing for macroscopic behavior and the ability to treat it quantitatively is growing in both Earth sciences and materials engineering. The results of this project will provide a framework for future efforts in both fields, and for collaborations between them. The project will contribute to the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce through training of graduate and undergraduate students and in participation of women in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Movement of Earth’s tectonic plates relative to one another causes a buildup of elastic energy in Earth’s upper crust. This elastic energy is periodically released in discrete events causing earthquakes. Less than 20% of the released energy travels through Earth in the form of seismic waves that cause ground shaking. The remaining energy is partitioned into frictional heat and brittle damage of rocks surrounding the fault surface. Around large continental strike-slip faults, like the San Andreas fault in California, this damage strongly influences the bulk elastic properties, which in turn influences particle velocities, seismic waves, and earthquake intensity. These damaged rocks are therefore of first-order importance in our understanding of seismic hazards.

The principal aims of this study were to: (1) develop a numerical methodology for the analysis of pervasive cracking in heterogeneous materials; (2) apply this numerical framework to study cracking in heterogeneous and polycrystalline microstructures to help quantify the effects of damage on seismic anisotropy; (3) determine the spatial and temporal pattern of damage around an ancient strike-slip fault exhumed from frictional-to-viscous transition depths; (4) develop a conceptual model linking this pattern to the damage structure of active faults observed at the surface; and (5) disseminate open-source software for damage analysis and calculation of bulk elastic properties of damaged rocks.

 

Below we outline the progress made on these aims.

1 and 2.  We have developed and published a numerical modeling approach for progressive grain-scale damage of polycrystalline aggregates. Some features of the smear crack band model include: (1) development and implementation of a constitutive formulation in which the dissipated energy is insensitive to the size of the finite elements, (2) development of a crack tracking algorithm for the reduction of directional mesh bias so that the crack propagation direction is not very sensitive to the structure and orientation of the finite element mesh, (3) reduction of stress-locking behavior that plagues conventional fixed crack models while allowing cracks to form at different orientations, (4) the use of sequentially linear analysis procedure in place of an iterative method to avoid instability issues and to capture the snap-type behavior of brittle materials and (5) simulation of intragranular and transgranular fracture propagation in anisotropic polycrystalline materials. The smeared crack band model has been used to study progressive damage in heterogeneous materials. The numerical framework can be used to quantify the effects of coseismic damage on seismic anisotropy.

3 and 4. We completed a comprehensive study of deformation microstructures from traverses across the Sandhill Corner shear zone, a strand of the Norumbega fault system in Maine, USA. The Norumbega fault system is well known to be an excellent ancient analog of the San Andreas fault in California, allowing us to investigate how deep brittle damage occurs in these types of faults. The rocks we examined were at depths of approximately 10-15 kilometers when this fault was seismically active. At these depths, brittle damage in minerals like quartz is rapidly healed, so they appear on casual observation to have not been affected by earthquake-related brittle damage. Using sophisticated analytical techniques employing a scanning electron microscope, we have found that quartz retains a memory of the seismic cycle, and can therefore be used to estimate the extent of brittle damage at depth. These observations have allowed us to develop a conceptual model of damage that links our observations with the damage structure around active faults observed at the surface.

5. The modeling methodology and example applications have been published, and we have lodged a new version of our MATLAB-based toolbox on the internet for public use at the following URL (inclusion of the fracture propagation component of the code in the publicly available version is still in progress):

Thermo-Elastic and Seismic Analysis (TESA) Toolbox for Polycrystalline Materials. https://umaine.edu/mecheng/vel/software/tesa_toolbox/

The overall broader impacts of this research are described below.

1. This project supported in whole or part the thesis work of three Ph.D. students and one M.S. student, including one female student. This training included interaction with the PIs in the field, in numerical modeling, and in the use of the electron microprobe and scanning electron microscope.

2. This project supported in part the development of two software packages used to evaluate the elastic and viscous properties of rocks. Both software packages are used in courses taught by the PIs, and are freely available for public use.

3. Grant-funded research lead to eight published papers, one published book chapter, one paper accepted with revision, one paper submitted for publication, five papers in preparation, and thirteen published conference abstracts.
